thread.title: Significant damage left behind by overnight storms in Gilmer County
thread.title_full: Significant damage left behind by overnight storms in Gilmer County

author: Jennifer Lifsey
title: Significant damage left behind by overnight storms in Gilmer County
text:
ELLIJAY, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Gilmer County residents woke up to significant damage caused by the overnight storms.
Severe weather rolled through and caused damage on Ellington Road at Old Highway 5 in Ellijay.
The area was under a tornado warning from around 10:45 p.m. until 11:15 p.m. It is unclear if the damage was caused by an actual tornado until the National Weather Service surveys the area.
LIVE UPDATES: Tornado watch issued until 1 p.m.
#Breaking : More substantial storm damage in Ellijay on Old HWY 5 and Ellington Road. Live updates on @ATLNewsFirst . pic.twitter.com/NSU0Yg8NcQ
— Adam Murphy (@AdamMurphyTV) May 9, 2024 FIRST ALERT WEATHER DAY | Storms expected through 3 p.m. Thursday Gilmer County Schools is closed Thursday due to the severe weather, as a second round of storms was expected. The district announced late Thursday afternoon that classes are also canceled Friday because of road conditions and power outages.
Due to ongoing road conditions and power outages, The Gilmer County School System will cancel classes for Friday May...
Posted by Gilmer County Schools on Thursday, May 9, 2024 A warming center is now open at 1561 S Main St. in Ellijay for residents in need of shelter.
The center is open NOW for anyone in need of shelter. Pets welcome and will be provided a kennel. Enter through side door by tennis courts. For transportation or information call 706/889-6109
Posted by The Gilmer County Warming Center on Thursday, May 9, 2024 William Buckner lives in Gilmer County and was stunned at the debris in his yard.
“It came in so quick,” Buckner said.
His family has owned land off Old Highway 5 in Ellijay for nearly 80 years and he’s never seen storm damage like this before.
“It came from all directions, and it’s just like it sat down on top of us right here, and you can see where it messed everything up,” Buckner said.
Buckner said the storms rolled in around 5 a.m. Thursday along Ellington Road and left a path of destruction behind.
Autoplay “I went back in the house, and I told my wife to get down. We got down and about 20 minutes later it was gone,” Buckner said.
His yard is littered with pieces of tin roofing, two-by-fours, and power lines. Some of the debris came from a damaged storage facility belonging to the Georgia Forestry Commission.
“It sounded more like the wind whistling, and it came out of this side. It just wrapped around. It just wrapped around us,” Buckner said.
Luckily, the Buckner family survived the wrath, but faces a long road to recovery.
“I went right in the house in the nick of time, and it just tore everything up,” Buckner said.
Return to Atlanta News First for updates on this developing story.
